title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 55 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies profit-maximizing quantity as 55 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns positive economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is below the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is greater than the average total cost, or P > ATC MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

The response states that the firm earns positive economic profit and explains that the firm’s average total cost curve is below the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is greater than the average total cost, or P > ATC MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate NanoWare’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $1,872 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$26×72=$1,872 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5FED@

The response calculates NanoWare’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $1,872 and shows the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$26×72=$1,872 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5FED@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at that price ($26) the firm will continue to produce and not shut down in the short run and/or does not explain it’s because the price is above the average variable cost and the average total cost which means the firm generates enough revenue to pay for both its variable costs and its fixed costs, so the firm makes positive economic profit, but if it shuts down it makes a loss equal to its fixed costs.

The response states that at that price ($26) the firm will continue to produce and not shut down in the short run and explains it’s because the price is above the average variable cost and the average total cost which means the firm generates enough revenue to pay for both its variable costs and its fixed costs, so the firm makes positive economic profit, but if it shuts down it makes a loss equal to its fixed costs.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the new average total cost as $25 and/or does not show the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $22×72+$216 72 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7BFA@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$22+ $216 72 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7F59@

The response calculates the new average total cost as $25 and shows the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $22×72+$216 72 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7BFA@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$22+ $216 72 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7F59@

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, HotCode has a dominant strategy and/or does not explain that HotCode’s payoff is always higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,200> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ and $4,600> $4,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B6@ ) regardless of whether NanoWare chooses to lower or maintain its price; or explain that when NanoWare chooses to lower its price, HotCode’s payoff is higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,200> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ ), and when NanoWare chooses to maintain its price, HotCode’s payoff is higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,600> $4,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B6@ ); therefore, HotCode’s dominant strategy is to not advertise.

The response states that yes, HotCode has a dominant strategy and explains that HotCode’s payoff is always higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,200> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ and $4,600> $4,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B6@ ) regardless of whether NanoWare chooses to lower or maintain its price; or explains that when NanoWare chooses to lower its price, HotCode’s payoff is higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,200> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ ), and when NanoWare chooses to maintain its price, HotCode’s payoff is higher when it chooses to not advertise ( $4,600> $4,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B6@ ); therefore, HotCode’s dominant strategy is to not advertise.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Nash equilibrium as NanoWare maintains its price and HotCode does not advertise with payoffs of ($2,000, $4,600) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F5@ , and/or does not explain that if NanoWare chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $2,000 to $1,000, and if HotCode chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $4,600 to $4,400; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies Nash equilibrium as NanoWare maintains its price and HotCode does not advertise with payoffs of ($2,000, $4,600) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F5@ , and explains that if NanoWare chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $2,000 to $1,000, and if HotCode chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $4,600 to $4,400; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and/or does not explain that the new strategies will be for NanoWare to lower its price and HotCode to advertise with payoffs of ($3,000, $4,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F5@ and explain that with the offer HotCode would earn $4,500 ( =$4,000 + $500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@429B@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $4,200 (with not advertising), and NanoWare would earn $3,000 ( =$3,500−$500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4197@ ) when choosing to lower the price compared to $2,500 ( =$3,000−$500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4192@ with maintaining the price); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explain that with the offer HotCode’s dominant strategy will change to advertise because its payoff will always be higher ( $4,500> $4,200 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B3@ and $4,900> $4,600 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42BB@ ) and since NanoWare has no dominant strategy it is better off to lower the price ( $3,000> $2,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the new strategies will be for NanoWare to lower its price and HotCode to advertise with payoffs of ($3,000, $4,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F5@ and explain that with the offer HotCode would earn $4,500 ( =$4,000 + $500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@429B@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $4,200 (with not advertising), and NanoWare would earn $3,000 ( =$3,500−$500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4197@ ) when choosing to lower the price compared to $2,500 ( =$3,000−$500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4192@ with maintaining the price); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explains that with the offer HotCode’s dominant strategy will change to advertise because its payoff will always be higher ( $4,500> $4,200 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B3@ and $4,900> $4,600 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42BB@ ) and since NanoWare has no dominant strategy it is better off to lower the price ( $3,000> $2,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AE@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
